title: Full Stack Web Development
summary: Master both frontend and backend development, databases, APIs, and deployment to build complete web applications.

steps.title: HTML & CSS (3-4 weeks)
steps.description: Learn semantic HTML5, CSS Grid, Flexbox, responsive design, and CSS animations. Build 3+ practice projects including portfolio, landing page, and blog layout.

quiz.question: What does HTML stand for?
quiz.explanation: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard markup language for creating web pages.

quiz.question: Which HTML5 element is used for the main content of a document?
quiz.explanation: The <main> element represents the dominant content of the body of a document.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of semantic HTML?
options: To provide meaningful structure and improve accessibility
quiz.explanation: Semantic HTML uses meaningful tags that clearly describe their purpose, improving accessibility and SEO.

quiz.question: Which CSS property is used to change text color?
quiz.explanation: The 'color' property sets the foreground color (usually text) of an element.

quiz.question: What does CSS stand for?
quiz.explanation: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets, used to style and layout web pages.

quiz.question: Which Flexbox property controls the direction of flex items?
quiz.explanation: The flex-direction property defines the main axis direction: row, row-reverse, column, or column-reverse.

quiz.question: In CSS Grid, what does 'fr' unit represent?
quiz.explanation: The 'fr' unit represents a fraction of the available space in the grid container.

quiz.question: Which property is used to align items along the cross axis in Flexbox?
quiz.explanation: The align-items property aligns flex items along the cross axis of the flex container.

quiz.question: What is the correct syntax for a CSS media query for screens smaller than 768px?
quiz.explanation: Media queries use max-width for upper bounds: @media screen and (max-width: 768px).

quiz.question: Which CSS Box Model layer is between padding and margin?
quiz.explanation: The Box Model order from inside out is: content, padding, border, margin.

quiz.question: What is the default value of the position property in CSS?
quiz.explanation: The default position value is 'static', which follows the normal document flow.

quiz.question: Which CSS property creates rounded corners?
quiz.explanation: The border-radius property creates rounded corners on elements.

quiz.question: What does the 'z-index' property control?
quiz.explanation: The z-index property controls the stacking order of overlapping elements.

quiz.question: Which unit is relative to the viewport width?
quiz.explanation: The 'vw' (viewport width) unit is 1% of the viewport's width.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the 'alt' attribute in tags?
options: To provide alternative text for accessibility
quiz.explanation: The alt attribute provides alternative text when images cannot be displayed and for screen readers.

quiz.question: Which CSS property controls the space between lines of text?
quiz.explanation: The line-height property sets the amount of space between lines of text.

quiz.question: What does the CSS 'display: none' property do?
quiz.explanation: display: none completely removes the element from the document flow, taking up no space.

quiz.question: Which HTML element creates an unordered list?
quiz.explanation: The <ul> element creates an unordered (bulleted) list.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to link an external CSS file?
quiz.explanation: Use <link rel='stylesheet' href='style.css'> in the <head> section to link external CSS.

quiz.question: Which CSS pseudo-class targets an element on mouse hover?
quiz.explanation: The :hover pseudo-class applies styles when the user hovers over an element with the mouse.

steps.title: JavaScript Fundamentals (4-6 weeks)
steps.description: Master variables, functions, arrays, objects, DOM manipulation, ES6+, async/await, and Fetch API. Build to-do list, calculator, weather app, and quiz application.

quiz.question: What is JavaScript primarily used for?
quiz.explanation: JavaScript is a programming language that enables interactive and dynamic behavior on websites.

quiz.question: Which keyword is used to declare a block-scoped variable in JavaScript?
quiz.explanation: 'let' declares a block-scoped variable that can be reassigned.

quiz.question: What is the difference between '==' and '===' in JavaScript?
options: === checks type and value, == only checks value
quiz.explanation: '===' (strict equality) checks both value and type, while '==' performs type coercion.

quiz.question: Which method adds an element to the end of an array?
quiz.explanation: The push() method adds one or more elements to the end of an array.

quiz.question: What does the DOM stand for?
quiz.explanation: DOM (Document Object Model) is a programming interface for HTML documents.

quiz.question: Which ES6 feature allows you to extract values from arrays or objects?
quiz.explanation: Destructuring allows unpacking values from arrays or properties from objects into distinct variables.

quiz.question: What does 'async/await' simplify in JavaScript?
options: Working with asynchronous code and Promises
quiz.explanation: async/await provides a cleaner syntax for working with asynchronous operations and Promises.

quiz.question: Which method is used to make HTTP requests in modern JavaScript?
quiz.explanation: The fetch() API provides a modern interface for making HTTP requests.

quiz.question: What is a closure in JavaScript?
options: A function that has access to variables in its outer scope
quiz.explanation: A closure is a function that retains access to variables from its containing scope.

quiz.question: Which array method creates a new array with results of calling a function on every element?
quiz.explanation: The map() method creates a new array by transforming each element with a callback function.

quiz.question: What does 'this' keyword refer to in JavaScript?
options: The global window object by default
The context in which it is called
quiz.explanation: 'this' refers to the object that is executing the current function, depending on how the function is called.

quiz.question: Which operator is used to spread array elements or object properties?
quiz.explanation: The spread operator (...) expands iterable elements or object properties.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of 'event.preventDefault()'?
options: Prevent the default action of an event
quiz.explanation: event.preventDefault() stops the browser's default behavior for an event (e.g., form submission).

quiz.question: Which method removes the last element from an array?
quiz.explanation: The pop() method removes and returns the last element of an array.

quiz.question: What is a Promise in JavaScript?
options: An object representing eventual completion or failure of an async operation
quiz.explanation: A Promise represents a value that may be available now, later, or never.

quiz.question: Which statement is used to handle errors in JavaScript?
quiz.explanation: The try-catch block is used to handle runtime errors gracefully.

quiz.question: What does JSON stand for?
quiz.explanation: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data interchange format.

quiz.question: Which method converts a JSON string to a JavaScript object?
quiz.explanation: JSON.parse() parses a JSON string and returns a JavaScript object.

quiz.question: What is the output of: typeof null?
quiz.explanation: typeof null returns 'object', which is a known JavaScript quirk.

quiz.question: Which loop is best for iterating over array elements in modern JavaScript?
quiz.explanation: The for...of loop provides a clean syntax for iterating over iterable objects like arrays.

steps.title: Git & GitHub (1 week)
steps.description: Learn Git basics, branching, merging, pull requests, and GitHub workflows.

quiz.question: What is Git?
quiz.explanation: Git is a distributed version control system that tracks changes in source code during development.

quiz.question: Which command initializes a new Git repository?
quiz.explanation: 'git init' creates a new Git repository in the current directory.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of 'git clone'?
options: To copy a remote repository to your local machine
quiz.explanation: 'git clone' creates a local copy of a remote repository.

quiz.question: Which command stages files for commit?
quiz.explanation: 'git add' stages changes to be included in the next commit.

quiz.question: What does 'git commit -m "message"' do?
options: Creates a snapshot with a descriptive message
quiz.explanation: 'git commit' saves staged changes with a commit message describing the changes.

quiz.question: Which command shows the status of working directory and staging area?
quiz.explanation: 'git status' displays which files are staged, unstaged, or untracked.

quiz.question: What is a branch in Git?
quiz.explanation: A branch allows you to develop features or fixes in isolation from the main codebase.

quiz.question: Which command creates and switches to a new branch?
quiz.explanation: 'git checkout -b branch-name' creates a new branch and switches to it in one command.

quiz.question: What does 'git merge' do?
quiz.explanation: 'git merge' integrates changes from one branch into another.

quiz.question: Which command uploads local commits to a remote repository?
quiz.explanation: 'git push' sends your local commits to the remote repository.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of 'git pull'?
options: To fetch and merge changes from remote
quiz.explanation: 'git pull' fetches changes from the remote and merges them into your current branch.

quiz.question: What is a merge conflict?
options: When Git can't automatically merge changes
quiz.explanation: A merge conflict occurs when Git can't automatically reconcile differences between branches.

quiz.question: Which file tells Git which files to ignore?
quiz.explanation: The .gitignore file specifies which files and directories Git should ignore.

quiz.question: What is GitHub?
options: A cloud-based Git repository hosting service
quiz.explanation: GitHub is a platform for hosting Git repositories and collaborating on code.

quiz.question: What is a Pull Request (PR)?
options: A request to merge code changes
quiz.explanation: A Pull Request proposes changes and requests code review before merging.

quiz.question: Which command shows commit history?
quiz.explanation: 'git log' displays the commit history of the repository.

quiz.question: What does 'git reset' do?
options: Unstages or moves HEAD to a different commit
quiz.explanation: 'git reset' can unstage files or move the current branch to a different commit.

quiz.question: What is the default branch name in a new Git repository?
quiz.explanation: The default branch is traditionally 'master' but many systems now use 'main'.

quiz.question: Which command shows differences between commits, branches, or working directory?
quiz.explanation: 'git diff' displays changes between various Git states.

quiz.question: What is 'git stash' used for?
quiz.explanation: 'git stash' temporarily stores uncommitted changes so you can switch branches cleanly.

steps.title: React.js (6-8 weeks)
steps.description: Master React components, props, state, hooks, Router, Context API, and state management. Build e-commerce catalog, social dashboard, movie search, and recipe app.

quiz.question: What is React?
options: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces
quiz.explanation: React is a JavaScript library developed by Facebook for creating interactive UIs.

quiz.question: What is JSX?
quiz.explanation: JSX is a syntax extension that allows writing HTML-like code in JavaScript.

quiz.question: What is a React component?
quiz.explanation: Components are independent, reusable pieces that make up a React application.

quiz.question: Which hook is used to manage state in functional components?
quiz.explanation: useState is a React Hook that adds state to functional components.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of useEffect?
options: To perform side effects like data fetching
quiz.explanation: useEffect handles side effects such as API calls, subscriptions, or manual DOM manipulation.

quiz.question: How do you pass data from parent to child component?
quiz.explanation: Props (properties) are used to pass data from parent to child components.

quiz.question: What is the Virtual DOM?
options: A lightweight copy of the real DOM
quiz.explanation: The Virtual DOM is an in-memory representation that React uses for efficient updates.

quiz.question: Which method is called when a component is first rendered?
quiz.explanation: componentDidMount is called after the component is inserted into the DOM (for class components).

quiz.question: What is the purpose of React Router?
quiz.explanation: React Router enables client-side routing for single-page applications.

quiz.question: What is the correct way to update state in React?
options: Using setState or state setter function
quiz.explanation: State should be updated using setState (class) or the setter function from useState (functional).

quiz.question: What is lifting state up in React?
options: Moving state to a higher position on screen
Moving state to a common ancestor component
quiz.explanation: Lifting state up means moving state to the closest common ancestor to share it between components.

quiz.question: What is the Context API used for?
quiz.explanation: Context API provides a way to pass data through the component tree without manually passing props.

quiz.question: What is a key prop used for in React lists?
options: Helping React identify which items changed
quiz.explanation: Keys help React identify which items have changed, been added, or removed for efficient updates.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of useRef?
options: To create references to DOM elements or mutable values
quiz.explanation: useRef returns a mutable ref object that persists across re-renders, useful for DOM access.

quiz.question: Which is the correct way to handle events in React?
quiz.explanation: React uses camelCase event handlers passed as functions: onClick={handleClick}.

quiz.question: What is Redux?
quiz.explanation: Redux is a predictable state container for managing global application state.

quiz.question: What is a Higher-Order Component (HOC)?
options: A component that renders other components
A function that takes a component and returns a new component
quiz.explanation: An HOC is an advanced pattern for reusing component logic by wrapping components.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of useMemo?
quiz.explanation: useMemo memoizes computed values to avoid expensive recalculations on every render.

quiz.question: What is conditional rendering in React?
options: Rendering based on CSS media queries
quiz.explanation: Conditional rendering displays different UI based on application state or props.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of useCallback?
options: To call a function multiple times
quiz.explanation: useCallback returns a memoized callback to prevent unnecessary re-creation of functions.

steps.title: Node.js & Express.js (4-6 weeks)
steps.description: Backend development with Node.js, Express routing, middleware, REST APIs, authentication, error handling, and security.

quiz.question: What is Node.js?
options: A JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine
quiz.explanation: Node.js allows JavaScript to run on the server side, outside of a browser.

quiz.question: Which module system does Node.js use by default?
quiz.explanation: Node.js uses CommonJS module system with require() and module.exports.

quiz.question: What is Express.js?
options: A minimal and flexible Node.js web framework
quiz.explanation: Express.js is a popular web application framework for Node.js.

quiz.question: What is middleware in Express?
options: Functions that execute during request-response cycle
quiz.explanation: Middleware functions have access to request, response objects and can modify them or end the cycle.

quiz.question: Which HTTP method is used to retrieve data?
quiz.explanation: GET requests are used to retrieve data from a server.

quiz.question: Which HTTP method creates a new resource?
quiz.explanation: POST requests are typically used to create new resources on the server.

quiz.question: What is REST API?
quiz.explanation: REST is an architectural style for designing networked applications using HTTP methods.

quiz.question: What does JWT stand for?
quiz.explanation: JWT (JSON Web Token) is a compact way to securely transmit information between parties.

quiz.question: Which method is used to define a route in Express?
quiz.explanation: Express uses methods like app.get(), app.post(), app.put() to define routes.

quiz.question: What is NPM?
quiz.explanation: NPM is the default package manager for Node.js, used to install and manage dependencies.

quiz.question: How do you handle errors in Express?
quiz.explanation: Express error-handling middleware takes 4 parameters: (err, req, res, next).

quiz.question: What is CORS?
quiz.explanation: CORS is a mechanism that allows restricted resources to be requested from another domain.

quiz.question: Which module parses incoming JSON request bodies in Express?
quiz.explanation: express.json() middleware parses incoming JSON payloads.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of app.use() in Express?
quiz.explanation: app.use() mounts middleware functions that execute for all or specific routes.

quiz.question: Which status code indicates a successful request?
quiz.explanation: HTTP status code 200 indicates a successful OK response.

quiz.question: What is environment variable in Node.js?
quiz.explanation: Environment variables store configuration and sensitive data outside the codebase.

quiz.question: How do you access environment variables in Node.js?
quiz.explanation: process.env object contains environment variables in Node.js.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of next() in Express middleware?
options: To pass control to the next middleware
quiz.explanation: Calling next() passes control to the next middleware function in the stack.

quiz.question: Which HTTP method updates an entire resource?
quiz.explanation: PUT requests replace an entire resource with new data.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of bcrypt in Node.js?
quiz.explanation: bcrypt is used to hash and securely store passwords.

steps.title: Databases (3-4 weeks)
steps.description: SQL (PostgreSQL/MySQL) and NoSQL (MongoDB) databases, CRUD operations, joins, relationships, indexing, and optimization.

quiz.question: What is a database?
options: An organized collection of structured data
quiz.explanation: A database is an organized system for storing, managing, and retrieving data.

quiz.question: What does SQL stand for?
quiz.explanation: SQL (Structured Query Language) is used to communicate with relational databases.

quiz.question: Which SQL command retrieves data from a database?
quiz.explanation: The SELECT statement is used to query and retrieve data from database tables.

quiz.question: What does CRUD stand for?
quiz.explanation: CRUD represents the four basic database operations: Create, Read, Update, and Delete.

quiz.question: What is a primary key?
options: The first column in a table
A unique identifier for each record
quiz.explanation: A primary key uniquely identifies each record in a database table.

quiz.question: What is a foreign key?
options: A field that links two tables together
quiz.explanation: A foreign key establishes a relationship between two tables by referencing a primary key.

quiz.question: Which type of JOIN returns all rows from both tables?
quiz.explanation: FULL OUTER JOIN returns all rows from both tables, with NULL values where no match exists.

quiz.question: What is MongoDB?
quiz.explanation: MongoDB is a NoSQL database that stores data in flexible JSON-like documents.

quiz.question: What is a collection in MongoDB?
quiz.explanation: In MongoDB, a collection is a group of documents, similar to a table in relational databases.

quiz.question: What is indexing in databases?
options: A technique to speed up query performance
quiz.explanation: Indexing creates data structures that improve the speed of data retrieval operations.

quiz.question: Which SQL command adds new data to a table?
quiz.explanation: The INSERT statement adds new rows of data to a database table.

quiz.question: What does normalization in databases mean?
quiz.explanation: Normalization organizes database structure to minimize data redundancy and improve integrity.

quiz.question: What is Mongoose?
options: An ODM library for MongoDB and Node.js
quiz.explanation: Mongoose is an Object Data Modeling (ODM) library that provides schema-based modeling for MongoDB.

quiz.question: Which SQL command modifies existing data?
quiz.explanation: The UPDATE statement modifies existing records in a database table.

quiz.question: What is a schema in databases?
options: The structure and organization of data
quiz.explanation: A schema defines the structure, organization, and constraints of data in a database.

quiz.question: What does ACID stand for in database transactions?
quiz.explanation: ACID properties ensure reliable processing of database transactions.

quiz.question: Which SQL clause filters query results?
quiz.explanation: The WHERE clause filters records based on specified conditions.

quiz.question: What is a NoSQL database advantage?
quiz.explanation: NoSQL databases offer flexible schemas and scale horizontally across multiple servers.

quiz.question: Which command removes data from a table?
quiz.explanation: The DELETE statement removes rows from a database table based on conditions.

quiz.question: What is a transaction in databases?
options: A sequence of operations treated as a single unit
quiz.explanation: A transaction is a sequence of database operations that execute as a single logical unit of work.

steps.title: API Development (3-4 weeks)
steps.description: Build RESTful and GraphQL APIs. Learn HTTP methods, versioning, documentation with Swagger, and API security best practices.

quiz.question: What does API stand for?
quiz.explanation: API (Application Programming Interface) enables communication between different software systems.

quiz.question: What is REST?
quiz.explanation: REST is an architectural style for designing networked applications using stateless communication.

quiz.question: Which HTTP status code indicates a resource was successfully created?
quiz.explanation: HTTP status code 201 indicates successful resource creation.

quiz.question: What is JSON?
quiz.explanation: JSON is a lightweight data format commonly used for API communication.

quiz.question: What is an endpoint in an API?
options: A URL where an API can access resources
quiz.explanation: An endpoint is a specific URL path where an API receives requests for particular resources.

quiz.question: What is GraphQL?
quiz.explanation: GraphQL is a query language that allows clients to request exactly the data they need.

quiz.question: Which HTTP method is idempotent and used for full updates?
quiz.explanation: PUT is idempotent and replaces an entire resource with new data.

quiz.question: What is API versioning?
options: Managing different API versions for backward compatibility
quiz.explanation: API versioning allows maintaining multiple versions to prevent breaking existing clients.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of API documentation?
options: To explain how to use the API endpoints
quiz.explanation: API documentation provides clear instructions on how to interact with API endpoints.

quiz.question: What is Swagger/OpenAPI?
options: A specification for documenting REST APIs
quiz.explanation: Swagger/OpenAPI is a standard for describing and documenting RESTful APIs.

quiz.question: What is rate limiting in APIs?
options: Restricting number of requests in a time period
quiz.explanation: Rate limiting prevents abuse by limiting the number of API requests per user/IP.

quiz.question: Which status code indicates 'Resource Not Found'?
quiz.explanation: HTTP status code 404 indicates the requested resource was not found.

quiz.question: What is WebSocket?
quiz.explanation: WebSocket enables real-time, bidirectional communication between client and server.

quiz.question: What is API authentication?
options: Verifying the identity of API users
quiz.explanation: API authentication ensures only authorized users can access protected endpoints.

quiz.question: What does HATEOAS stand for in REST?
options: HTTP And The End Of API Services
Hypermedia As The Engine Of Application State
Handling All Types Of API States
Hypertext Access To External Online API Services
quiz.explanation: HATEOAS is a REST constraint where API responses include links to related actions.

quiz.question: Which HTTP header specifies the media type of the resource?
quiz.explanation: Content-Type header indicates the media type (e.g., application/json) of the request or response body.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of PATCH HTTP method?
quiz.explanation: PATCH is used to apply partial modifications to a resource.

quiz.question: What is API gateway?
options: A single entry point that routes requests to microservices
quiz.explanation: An API gateway manages, routes, and secures requests to backend microservices.

quiz.question: Which status code indicates unauthorized access?
quiz.explanation: HTTP status code 401 indicates authentication is required or has failed.

quiz.question: What is the advantage of GraphQL over REST?
options: Clients can request exactly the data they need
quiz.explanation: GraphQL allows clients to specify exactly what data they need, avoiding over-fetching or under-fetching.

steps.title: Testing (2-3 weeks)
steps.description: Unit testing with Jest/Vitest, React Testing Library, E2E testing with Cypress/Playwright, TDD methodology.

quiz.question: What is unit testing?
options: Testing individual units or components of code
quiz.explanation: Unit testing verifies that individual functions or components work correctly in isolation.

quiz.question: What is Jest?
quiz.explanation: Jest is a popular JavaScript testing framework developed by Facebook.

quiz.question: What does TDD stand for?
quiz.explanation: TDD is a methodology where tests are written before the actual code implementation.

quiz.question: What is an assertion in testing?
options: A statement that checks if a condition is true
quiz.explanation: Assertions verify that the actual output matches expected output in tests.

quiz.question: What is React Testing Library used for?
options: Testing React components from user perspective
quiz.explanation: React Testing Library tests components by simulating user interactions.

quiz.question: What does E2E testing mean?
quiz.explanation: End-to-End testing validates complete user workflows from start to finish.

quiz.question: What is Cypress?
options: An E2E testing framework for web applications
quiz.explanation: Cypress is a popular end-to-end testing framework that runs tests in the browser.

quiz.question: What is code coverage?
options: Percentage of code executed by tests
quiz.explanation: Code coverage measures the percentage of code that is executed during testing.

quiz.question: What is mocking in tests?
quiz.explanation: Mocking replaces real dependencies with controlled fake versions for testing purposes.

quiz.question: What is integration testing?
options: Testing how multiple modules work together
quiz.explanation: Integration testing verifies that different parts of the application work correctly together.

quiz.question: Which test type is fastest to run?
quiz.explanation: Unit tests are typically the fastest because they test small, isolated pieces of code.

quiz.question: What is a test suite?
options: A collection of related test cases
quiz.explanation: A test suite is a collection of test cases that are grouped together.

quiz.question: What is Playwright?
options: A modern E2E testing framework for web apps
quiz.explanation: Playwright is a framework for end-to-end testing that supports multiple browsers.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of beforeEach() in testing?
options: To run code after each test
To run setup code before each test
quiz.explanation: beforeEach() executes setup code before each test case runs.

quiz.question: What is snapshot testing?
options: Comparing component output against saved snapshots
quiz.explanation: Snapshot testing compares current component output with previously saved output.

quiz.question: What is a test double?
options: A generic term for mocks, stubs, and spies
quiz.explanation: Test double is an umbrella term for objects that replace real dependencies in tests.

quiz.question: What is continuous testing?
quiz.explanation: Continuous testing automatically runs tests as part of the development pipeline.

quiz.question: What is AAA pattern in testing?
quiz.explanation: AAA pattern structures tests: Arrange setup, Act on the code, Assert the result.

quiz.question: What is regression testing?
options: Testing old features after changes to ensure they still work
quiz.explanation: Regression testing ensures new changes don't break existing functionality.

quiz.question: What is Vitest?
options: A fast unit test framework for Vite projects
quiz.explanation: Vitest is a blazing fast unit testing framework powered by Vite.

steps.title: DevOps & Deployment (3-4 weeks)
steps.description: Master Docker containerization, CI/CD with GitHub Actions, cloud deployment (AWS/Heroku), Kubernetes basics, and monitoring with Prometheus.

quiz.question: What is Docker?
options: A containerization platform for packaging applications
quiz.explanation: Docker packages applications and dependencies into portable containers.

quiz.question: What is a container?
quiz.explanation: Containers package software with all dependencies for consistent execution across environments.

quiz.question: What does CI/CD stand for?
quiz.explanation: CI/CD automates the process of integrating code changes and deploying to production.

quiz.question: What is a Dockerfile?
options: A text file with instructions to build a Docker image
quiz.explanation: A Dockerfile contains commands to assemble a Docker image layer by layer.

quiz.question: What is Kubernetes?
options: An orchestration platform for managing containers
quiz.explanation: Kubernetes automates deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

quiz.question: What is GitHub Actions?
options: A CI/CD automation platform integrated with GitHub
quiz.explanation: GitHub Actions automates workflows including testing, building, and deployment.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of environment variables in deployment?
options: To store configuration and secrets separately from code
quiz.explanation: Environment variables manage configuration without hardcoding sensitive data.

quiz.question: What is Vercel?
options: A platform for deploying frontend applications
quiz.explanation: Vercel is a cloud platform optimized for deploying frontend frameworks like Next.js.

quiz.question: What is a build pipeline?
options: An automated sequence of steps to build and deploy code
quiz.explanation: A build pipeline automates compiling, testing, and deploying applications.

quiz.question: What is monitoring in DevOps?
options: Tracking application performance and errors in production
quiz.explanation: Monitoring tracks system health, performance metrics, and detects issues in real-time.

quiz.question: What is HTTPS?
quiz.explanation: HTTPS encrypts data transmission between client and server for security.

quiz.question: What is Docker Compose?
options: A tool for defining multi-container applications
quiz.explanation: Docker Compose defines and runs multi-container Docker applications using YAML files.

quiz.question: What is a CDN?
quiz.explanation: CDN is a distributed network that delivers content quickly from servers closest to users.

quiz.question: What is load balancing?
quiz.explanation: Load balancing distributes network traffic to prevent server overload.

quiz.question: What is Nginx?
options: A web server and reverse proxy
quiz.explanation: Nginx is a high-performance web server, reverse proxy, and load balancer.

quiz.question: What is blue-green deployment?
options: Deploying with blue and green colors
A strategy with two identical production environments
quiz.explanation: Blue-green deployment reduces downtime by switching between two production environments.

quiz.question: What is Prometheus?
quiz.explanation: Prometheus collects and stores metrics for monitoring system performance.

quiz.question: What is Infrastructure as Code (IaC)?
options: Managing infrastructure through code rather than manual processes
quiz.explanation: IaC uses code to provision and manage infrastructure automatically and consistently.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of SSL certificates?
options: To encrypt data and verify website identity
quiz.explanation: SSL certificates enable HTTPS encryption and authenticate website identity.

quiz.question: What is auto-scaling?
options: Automatically adjusting resources based on demand
quiz.explanation: Auto-scaling dynamically adjusts computing resources based on application load.

steps.title: Best Practices (Ongoing)
steps.description: Clean code, design patterns, system design, code review, Agile/Scrum methodology.

quiz.question: What is clean code?
options: Code that is easy to read, understand, and maintain
quiz.explanation: Clean code emphasizes clarity, simplicity, and maintainability for other developers.

quiz.question: What does DRY principle stand for?
quiz.explanation: DRY principle advocates avoiding code duplication by reusing logic.

quiz.question: What is a design pattern?
options: A reusable solution to common software problems
quiz.explanation: Design patterns are proven solutions to recurring design problems in software.

quiz.question: What is refactoring?
options: Improving code structure without changing behavior
quiz.explanation: Refactoring restructures code to improve readability and maintainability without altering functionality.

quiz.question: What does SOLID stand for in OOP?
options: Single responsibility, Open-closed, Liskov substitution, Interface segregation, Dependency inversion
quiz.explanation: SOLID are five principles for writing maintainable object-oriented code.

quiz.question: What is technical debt?
options: Cost of rework caused by choosing quick solutions
quiz.explanation: Technical debt is the implied cost of additional rework due to choosing suboptimal solutions.

quiz.question: What is Agile methodology?
options: An iterative approach to project management
quiz.explanation: Agile emphasizes iterative development, collaboration, and responding to change.

quiz.question: What is a code review?
options: Examining code written by others for quality
quiz.explanation: Code reviews involve peers examining code to ensure quality, find bugs, and share knowledge.

quiz.question: What is Scrum?
options: An Agile framework with sprints and ceremonies
quiz.explanation: Scrum is an Agile framework that organizes work into time-boxed sprints.

quiz.question: What is a sprint in Agile?
options: A time-boxed iteration for completing work
quiz.explanation: A sprint is a fixed time period (usually 1-4 weeks) for completing planned work.

quiz.question: What is the Single Responsibility Principle?
options: A class should have one reason to change
quiz.explanation: SRP states that a class should have only one responsibility or reason to change.

quiz.question: What is pair programming?
options: Writing code in pairs of lines
Two developers working together on same code
quiz.explanation: Pair programming involves two developers collaborating at one workstation.

quiz.question: What is a code smell?
options: A surface indication of deeper code problems
quiz.explanation: Code smells are patterns suggesting potential problems in code design.

quiz.question: What is system design?
options: Architecting scalable and reliable software systems
quiz.explanation: System design involves planning architecture to meet scalability, reliability, and performance requirements.

quiz.question: What is the Open-Closed Principle?
options: Software entities should be open for extension, closed for modification
quiz.explanation: OCP states code should be extendable without modifying existing code.

quiz.question: What is a stand-up meeting in Agile?
options: A short daily meeting to sync team progress
quiz.explanation: Daily stand-ups are brief meetings where team members share progress and blockers.

quiz.question: What is technical documentation?
options: Written material explaining system architecture and code
quiz.explanation: Technical documentation explains how systems work for developers and maintainers.

quiz.question: What is the KISS principle?
quiz.explanation: KISS principle advocates for simplicity in design and avoiding unnecessary complexity.

quiz.question: What is separation of concerns?
options: Dividing program into distinct sections handling specific functionality
quiz.explanation: Separation of concerns means organizing code so each section addresses a specific aspect.

quiz.question: What is a retrospective in Agile?
options: A meeting to reflect on the sprint and improve
quiz.explanation: Retrospectives are meetings where teams discuss what went well and what to improve.
